0.text:
To most people,
mushroom clouds mean nuclear explosions:

5.text:
of mutually assured destruction
and of the end of the world.

9.text: But they don't have to be:

10.text:
any large enough explosion
will cause a mushroom cloud.

13.text: And it's happened in Britain: right here.

18.text:
This crater was once RAF Fauld,
an old mining operation

21.text:
converted to an underground bomb storage depot
for the Royal Air Force.

26.text: Underground storage was meant to be safer:

28.text:
one of the problems with munitions dumps is
that the enemy

31.text:
just needs to hit them with one bomb and the
whole lot goes up.

35.text:
This site seemed perfect:
but there was a problem.

39.text:
Because this was built in the 1930s
for small bombs,

43.text: the sort that one person can carry,

45.text: the sort that you can move on a conveyor belt,

46.text:
the sort that the Army can fire from
a field gun across the trenches.

51.text:
That's why these old quarries with all their
tunnels and caverns were perfect.

56.text: But then the Second World War moved on,

58.text: and bombing became a job for the Air Force,

60.text:
and the bombs got bigger and bigger and bigger,
fast: half a ton, one ton, two tons.

66.text:
And the war effort needed many, many
more bombs than had been predicted.

71.text:
Rapid changes in supply and demand meant that
the underground depots were filled

75.text: far beyond anything like their original capacity.

78.text:
By the end of 1944, the men here at RAF Fauld
were storing stacks of high incendiary bombs

85.text:
outside the mine
until they could find space inside.

90.text: They had to make it work.

95.text: The commanding officer was on leave.

98.text:
The officer responsible for the underground
stores was also on leave --

101.text: and it was his deputy's day off too.

104.text:
Everyone who was down in the depot and in
charge was inexperienced and massively overworked.

112.text:
someone tried to remove a detonator from a
live bomb with a brass chisel.

121.text:
In Morocco, 1500 miles away, seismographs
recorded what felt like a distant earthquake.

127.text:
A hundred miles away, people heard a rumble
carried on the wind.

131.text:
Four miles away,
a shock wave blasted out windows.

135.text: And here: a mushroom cloud rose into the sky.

139.text:
4,000 tonnes of bombs had gone up
in one terrible chain reaction,

143.text:
the largest explosion ever
in the British Isles.

146.text:
This crater was once a hill,
with a farmhouse on top of it:

150.text:
no trace of that farmhouse, or the people
who lived there, was ever found.

154.text:
The bombs that hadn't immediately exploded
were thrown into the air

157.text:
and rained down for miles around, along with
millions of tons of debris.

161.text:
A nearby dam collapsed, sending floodwaters
down into factories and houses in a nearby valley.

167.text:
The exact death toll will never be known;
at least 60, perhaps 90.

172.text:
It took months before all the bodies were
recovered, and some were never found.

177.text:
And in the Air Force reports, held classified
for years and years after the explosion,

183.text:
along with the names of the dead
and page after page

186.text:
itemising every bit of the destruction,
there is this phrase:

190.text:
"columns of black smoke and debris rose in
gigantic mushroom form".

197.text:
When you're rushed, when you're inexperienced,
anyone can get complacent,

201.text:
anyone can cut corners,
anyone can make a mistake.

207.text:
Now slowly, over years, the crater was cleared
and reclaimed; decades later,

213.text: what remains is an odd scar on the landscape.

216.text:
About half the bomb store actually managed
to survive the explosion;

220.text:
and while the bombs were removed, there are still
tunnels and storage rooms hidden under the crater.

227.text:
But after careless explorers
started damaging the site,

232.text: all the known entrances were filled in.

234.text:
And given the warnings about unexploded bombs
still in the crater,

238.text:
I'm not about to climb this fence
and go any further.

242.text: There is one little interesting note, though,

245.text: right at the end of the story:

249.text:
the American military kept asking for records
and details of the explosion.

255.text:
What was the damage to the nearby land,
and was it by earthquake or by blast wave?

262.text:
detonate something with the yield of a tactical
nuclear bomb underground?

268.text:
And America went on 
to make its own mushroom clouds.
